children.name: not by any mode or transport
đi bộ
examples: ▪ Anna missed the bus, so she decided to walk.

children.name: on foot
children.definition: if you go somewhereon foot,you walk instead of going by car, bus, train etc:
examples: ▪ It’s not far. It’ll take you about ten minutes on foot.
go on foot : đi bộ
▪ The bus left us at the bottom of the hill, and we went the rest of the way on foot.
on foot /ɒn ˈfʊt/ [adverb] if you go somewhere on foot, you walk there:
đi bộ , bằng cách đi bộ
▪ The two men had attempted to cross the mountains on foot.
on foot đi bộ
walking
_Are you going by bicycle or on foot?

children.name: wanderlust
children.definition: a strong desire to travel and to experience life in other countries: đi du lịch
examples: It was not wanderlust alone that made him keen to visit Brazil. He thought he might hear news of his natural mother there.
In July wanderlust takes over the whole nation.

children.name: itchy feet
children.definition: informalthe desire to travel, which makes it difficult for you to stay in one place for very long: ngứa chân ( muốn đi đây đi đó )

children.name: get itchy feetto start to want to travel or do something different
examples: I always get itchy feet at this time of year, in the spring.
After three years in the job she began to get itchy feet.

children.name: travel
children.definition: the activity of travelling: đi chuyển , đi lại
examples: The new job involves a fair amount of travel.
a travel writeran award-winning travel writer
COMMON ERRORS
►Do not use 'a travel' to meana journeyora trip, for example by saying 'a long/short travel'. Saya long/short journeyora long/short trip.

children.name: air travel
examples: There has been a major increase in air travel during the last twenty years.

children.name: rail travel
examples: The measures were introduced to make rail travel safer.

children.name: bus/coach/car etc travel
examples: The price is £98, inclusive of coach travel.

children.name: foreign/international/overseas travel
examples: The job offers opportunities for foreign travel.

children.name: long-distance travel
examples: Long-distance travel is becoming much more common these days.

children.name: business travel
examples: Business travel often took him away from his family.

children.name: space travel
examples: Large rockets are used for space travel and exploration.

children.name: the travel industry
examples: The storms have had a huge effect on the country's travel industry.

children.name: travel arrangements
examples: I still have to make all the travel arrangements.

children.name: travel expenses/costs
examples: They offered to pay my travel expenses.

children.name: travel insurance
examples: You are strongly advised to take out travel insurance.

children.name: a travel book/guide
examples: Kyushu looks so lovely in the travel books.

children.name: a form/mode/method/means of travel
examples: I find the train a more comfortable mode of travel.

children.name: to travel as part of your job
travel
children.definition: đi lại ( vì công việc )
examples: ▪ Do you have to travel a lot in your new job?
▪ The post will involve you travelling to Germany about three times a year.

children.name: tour
children.definition: if a sports team, entertainer, politician etc tours, they travel to many different places in order toplay,perform,or be seen: đi lưu diễn
examples: Haynes recorded with Charlie Parker and toured with Sarah Vaughan in the 1950s.
The theatre company will tour later this year.

children.name: tour the country/the US/Russia etc
examples: The team is currently touring Australia in a series of friendly games.

children.name: be on tour
children.definition: if a musician, actor, sportsman etc is on tour, he or she is travelling to many different places so that people can see them play or perform: đang lưu diễn
examples: ▪ Jennings is currently on tour, promoting and reading from his new children’s book.
▪ At the moment the band is on tour in Europe.

children.name: en route
children.definition: on the way to somewhere: trên đường
examples: We stopped en route to meet some friends in Brussels.
en route from/to
a flight en route from Tokyo to Sydney
The flight was en route from Tokyo to Sydney when it experienced engine trouble.
en route forBritish English:
We stayed there en route for London.
Why don’t we stop for lunch en route?

children.name: be on the move
children.definition: to travel from one place to another, especially because it isdifficultorimpossiblefor you to stay where you were: đi lại, đi chuyển,
examples: He was always on the move, never staying in one town more than a few days.
The guerrillas stay on the move to avoid capture.
Thousands of refugees are on the move, fleeing heavy shelling in their home towns.
We're going to be on the move all next week, but we'll call you when we get to Edinburgh.

children.name: to travel to a lot of different places
travel around
children.definition: / travel roundUK  to travel toa lot ofdifferent places, especially when youdo not planexactly where you are going:
examples: ▪ David travelled around a lot in the ‘60s and ’70s.

children.name: travel around Europe/the North/Canada etc
examples: ▪ I’d love to have a job that let me travel around the world.
▪ She’s been traveling around the country trying to get big companies interested in her ideas.

children.name: tour
children.definition: UK to travel to a lot of different placeswithin a particular area or country, especially forpleasureandinterest: đi du lịch
examples: ▪ For our summer vacation this year we’re touring Spain in a camper.
▪ We shall tour the city for two hours and then meet back at the bus.

children.name: do
children.definition: to travel to a lot of different placesin a particular area,especiallyas part of a holiday: đi du lịch ( quanh vùng nào )
examples: Last year we did the Greek Islands but we were thinking of the USA this year.
There’s not a whole lot to see, so you can do the city in two or three days.

children.name: get around
children.definition: / get roundUK  to travel to alargenumberof places, usuallyin a short time: đi lại
examples: The metro system in Mexico City is very good. It makes it really easy to get around.

children.name: get around London/Europe/the Midwest etc
examples: You can use free shuttle buses to get around the city.

children.name: explore
children.definition: to travel to many different places in aparticulararea, because you are interestedto find outmore about them: khám phá
examples: ▪ We’ll be in Istanbul for three days, so there will be plenty of time to explore.
▪ Whenever possible, she and Flynn would go off and explore the countryside, taking a picnic with them.

children.name: see the world U
children.definition: see the world to travel around to different places allover the worldso that you get the experience of living in other countries:
examples: After leaving college and earning some money he set off to see the world.

children.name: on your travels
children.definition: if youdosomethingon your travels, you do it while you are travelling to different places: khi đang đi du lịch
examples: ▪ I picked up a few words of Chinese on my travels, but I don’t speak it fluently.

children.name: on your travels to
examples: ▪ Corbett met a number of his contacts on his travels to Taiwan.

children.name: go abroad
children.definition: to travel to another country, especially forpleasureandinterest: đi ngước ngoài
examples: ▪ Here’s a list of things to think about before you go abroad.
▪ I’m the only person I know who’s never been abroad or even on a plane.

children.name: be abroad
examples: ▪ When their mother died she was unable to contact her brother because he was abroadsomewhere.

children.name: go overseas
children.definition: to travel to another country in orderto stay there for a long time, for example because you have been sent to work there:

children.name: đi sang hải ngoại
examples: ▪ I wrote a letter to the interviewer, explaining that I was going overseas for six months.
▪ The soldiers underwent training for three months before the unit went overseas.

children.name: visit
children.definition: to travel to another countryfor a short time, especially because you want tofind out what it is like:

children.name: đến thăm ( để biết về một nơi nào đó )
examples: ▪ He was the first traveller from the British Isles to visit Abyssinia.
▪ Thousands of Americans visit Thailand each year.

children.name: go out to Ugo out to  British
children.definition: to travel to another country that is along wayaway:

children.name: đi đến ( sang nước khác )
examples: ▪ He went out to West Africa in 1962 and has been there ever since.
▪ The Chief Financial Officer went out to Korea to oversee the merger.

children.name: to travel a particular distance or at a particular speed
go
children.definition: 40 miles/five kilometres etcto travel a particular distance, especially as onlypart of a journey: đi được ( bao nhiêu đoạn đường )
examples: We had only gone about five miles when I started to feel sick.
How far have we gone today?
It took us over an hour to go ten miles.
The car was going much too fast.
We went a different way from usual that day.

children.name: go[
examples: I or T] A1 to move or travel in a particular way :

children.name: do
children.definition: to travel aparticular distanceor to travel at aparticular speed
examples: My new car does 50 miles to the gallon/30 km to the litre (= uses one gallon of fuel to travel 50 miles, or one litre to travel 30 km) .
We were doing 150 (km an hour) along the motorway.

children.name: do 20 miles/30 kilometres etcto travel for 20 miles, 30 kilometres etc:đi được
examples: We were riding through the hills, but we still managed to do 30 miles each day.
I bought the car for £3500, and it’s only done 30,000 miles!
It's an old car and it's done over 80 000 miles.

children.name: cover
children.definition: to travel a particular distance, especially alongdistance, that is part of alongerjourneyyou are making: đi được
examples: It took him three days to cover the distance from Laingsbury to Albertsville.
In one twenty-five day period, he covered 800 miles.
We covered 400km in three hours.
They were hoping to cover 40 miles yesterday.
A leopard cancovera lot ofgroundvery quickly.

children.name: travel
children.definition: to go a particular distance or at a particular speed
examples: Supersonic planes can travel faster than the speed of sound.

children.name: travel at
examples: The train was travelling at 100 mph.
They travelled 200 miles on the first day.

children.name: to travel from one place to another
travel
children.definition: to go from one place to another, or to several places, especially ones that are far away:
examples: Someday I’d like totravel abroad.

children.name: travel abroad
examples: Only the affluent could afford to take vacations or to travel abroad.

children.name: travel widely/extensively
examples: He travelled extensively in Europe studying geology.

children.name: travel light
children.definition: not take many things with you
examples: The idea was to travel light, so Travis allowed her to pack only one change of clothing.

children.name: travel by train/car/air etc
examples: Emily hated travelling by train.

children.name: travel to/across/through/around etc
examples: We’re planning to travel across America this summer.

children.name: travel the world/countryto go to most parts of the world or of a particular country
examples: They travelled the world together.

children.name: commute
children.definition: to regularly travel a long distance to work or school.
examples: She commutes to work by bicycle.

children.name: commuter[
examples: C] sb who lives in a different town, city etc from the one where they work, and who therefore travels a long distance every day to get to work:

children.name: commute[
examples: C usually S] informal a journey that sb makes each day to work, especially when they live a fairly long way away from their work:

children.name: commute to/from/between
examples: Jim commutes to Manhattan every day.
It was a small shop that catered to commuters and local workers.
The train was packed with commuters.

children.name: commuter train/plane etc
examples: Each region has one organization controlling buses and operating its commuter trains.
The commute from Kent into London can be horrendous.

children.name: a 1-hour/20-minute etc commute
examples: I had no money, two small children, and a 90-minute commute to work each day.
It's at least an hour's commute to work.

children.name: go
children.definition: to go somewhere – often used instead oftravel:
examples: We’re going to Greece for our holidays this year.
He’s gone to London on business.
It’s quicker to go by plane.
go and do sth(alsogo do somethingAmerican English) [not in past tenses] to move to a particular place in order to do something :
Go wash your hands.
I went and spoke to the manager.

children.name: go by bus/train/car etc
examples: It’ll be quicker to go by train.

children.name: cross
children.definition: to travel across a verylargeareasuch as a desert, an ocean, or an area of mountains: băng qua
examples: It took a lot of courage to cross the Rocky Mountains in those days.
They crossed the Atlantic in a convoy of fifty ships.
The slaves crossed the Atlantic in the holds of the ships.

children.name: been U
children.definition: Have you ever been to(= have you ever travelled to )Japan?
examples: Ihave been to(= have travelled to )Germany several times.

children.name: backpacking
children.definition: the activity of travellingindependentlyto a lot ofdifferentareas, carrying your clothes etc in a special bag on your back: du lịch bụi, đeo ba lô đi du lịch
examples: Backpacking is especially popular among students and young people.
a backpacking trip
go backpacking
Last year, he went backpacking in the US.

children.name: roll
children.definition: If an aircraft or a ship rolls, it leans to one side and then to the other because of the wind or waves: tròng trành lộn vòng
examples: roll[U] The roll of a ship or aircraft is its movement from side to side in the water or air.

children.name: travelling
children.definition: UK /travelingUS  moving from place to place in order to work, perform etc: du lịch
examples: 1 travelling expensesmoney that is used to pay for the cost of travelling while someone is on a trip for their company
2 travelling companionsomeone you are on a journey with
3 travelling musician/circus/exhibition etcsomeone or something that goes from place to place
The traveling show includes historical films as well as 300 genuine artifacts that kids can handle.
His father was a travelling salesman and was very rarely at home.
4 travelling rug/clock etcBritish Englisha clock etc designed to be used when you are travelling
5 travelling people/folkBritish Englishtravellers
